model.dek: Cooking with rosemary, post-workout snacks, and more.

items.hed: Basic Method for Cooking Corn on the Cob

items.socialDescription: This rich 15-minute ragù turns pasta or polenta into a quick hearty dinner any night of the week.
items.dek: This rich 15-minute ragù turns pasta or polenta into a quick hearty dinner any night of the week.
items.promoDek: This rich 15-minute ragù turns pasta or polenta into a quick hearty dinner any night of the week.

steps.description: Cook pasta in a large pot of boiling salted water, stirring occasionally, until al dente; drain and transfer to a large bowl.
Meanwhile, process onion, celery, carrot, and garlic in a food processor until finely chopped.

Heat oil in a large skillet over high. Add chopped vegetables, beef, and pork and cook, breaking up with a spatula, until meat is beginning to brown, about 3 minutes. Stir in tomato paste, oregano, 3/4 tsp. salt, and 1/2 teaspoon pepper; cook, stirring occasionally, until heated through, about 1 minute. Add wine and cook, stirring constantly, until reduced by half, about 1 minute more. Stir in tomato sauce, reduce heat to medium, and simmer until sauce is slightly thickened, about 4 minutes.
Remove from heat, then stir in butter. Toss meat sauce with pasta, top with Parmesan, and season with pepper.
Let sauce cool, then chill in an airtight container for up to 3 days or freeze for up to 2 months.

fields.title: 15-minute Meat Sauce
fields.credit: Photo by Chelsea Kyle, Food Styling by Anna Stockwell

items.dek: Earthy and pungent, this herb packs one serious punch.
items.promoDek: Earthy and pungent, this herb packs one serious punch.

items.caption: These easy pan fried pork chops are the ultimate answer to crazed weeknights.
Use any leftover garlic-rosemary oil the next time you roast vegetables to add instant flavor.
Rosemary and potatoes are a classic pairing and this crowd-pleasing recipe proves it.
Who says shortbread always has to be super sweet? Rosemary and caraway make these sugar-dusted cookies slightly savory.
A simple sauce of Greek yogurt, horseradish, and white wine vinegar rounds out this one-pan dinner.
Serve the fish with roasted potatoes, creamy polenta, or cooked white beans, all of which will sop up the briny sauce.
Stuffed with a mix of green olives, garlic, rosemary, and orange peel, these grilled chicken breasts are packed with flavor.
As this recipe calls for a whole side of salmon, it makes an impressive main course for a crowd.
Sure, maple syrup is perfect as it, but infusing it with rosemary turns it on its head and makes it even more delicious.
Rosemary and mushrooms add earthy notes to this comforting pasta.
Consider your search for the ultimate fried chicken over—this version is the crispiest and juiciest you'll find.
Brining the almonds actually infuses flavor into them from the inside out, making them even more addictive.

items.seoDescription: Earthy and pungent, this herb packs one serious punch.
items.socialDescription: Earthy and pungent, this herb packs one serious punch.

items.dek: Replenish your energy with these good-for-you bites.
items.promoDek: Replenish your energy with these good-for-you bites.

items.caption: This healthy bowl is packed with superfoods and has the added benefit of a little caffeine kick from matcha powder.
Packed with nuts, seeds, and wheat germ, these maple syrup-sweetened bars are hearty and wholesome.
Using deli turkey or ham instead of bread not only makes these snack wraps gluten-free, it also gives them an extra protein boost.
Folding ricotta into scrambled eggs when they're almost done cooking makes them extra creamy and even more satisfying.
Avocado and chia seeds add healthy fats and richness to this fruity smoothie.

Dates add natural sweetness and fiber to these chewy bars. Just be sure to plan ahead—the bars cook at a low temperature for a few hours so it's best to make them ahead of time so you'll have them at the ready.
Build this yogurt parfait before you head out for your workout and store it in the fridge so it's ready to dig into when you get back.
These cute little rolls may look like sushi, but they are actually packed with tuna salad, cucumbers, and carrots.
If you're too tired after your workout to poach the egg, just scramble it instead.
You may think that yogurt and granola is only for breakfast, but since it combines carbohydrates and protein, it's just as good post-workout.
This healthy wrap can be whipped up in no time. For a little extra protein, add a couple of slices of cheese before you roll them up.

The best part of these bite-size snacks is how customizable they are—use whichever nut or seed butter you prefer and have fun rolling them in different coatings like unsweetened cocoa powder or coconut.
Inspired by the classic sandwich, you'll find yourself craving this smoothie long before your workout ends.

items.seoDescription: Replenish your energy with these good-for-you bites.
items.socialDescription: Replenish your energy with these good-for-you bites.

fields.title: Smoothie Bowl
fields.credit: Photo by Chelsea Kyle, food styling by Anna Stockwell

items.seoTitle: What Do I Do With Eggplant?
items.socialTitle: What Do I Do With Eggplant?
items.socialDescription: Take the nightshade beyond the watery mess with these eggplant recipes and tricks.

items.caption: Can you chip it? With eggplant, the answer is yes.
Cheesy pizza is good. Grilled cheesy pizza is *great*. It takes on a smoky dimension (here amplified by meaty grilled eggplant) that always leaves people clamoring for more.
Beat eggplant's bitter reputation with this tomato-rich Lebanese eggplant. Slowly simmering eggplant in tomato and allspice sweetens it up.
Tired of soggy stir-fry? Here's the problem: cooking everything at once. By adding the eggplant in batches, you can actually brown it instead of steaming it.
The classic eggplant Parmesan gets better with one little trick. By removing everything but a strip of the eggplant's skin, the vegetable holds together instead of falling apart.
Who needs tortillas when you have eggplant? Make these "tacos" of cilantro and brie on roasted eggplant rounds.
Grilling the greens doesn't have to be a scorch fest. Lay them across the grill grates so they don't fall through, and don't do anything else until they're finished.
We love heirloom tomatoes, but after a whole summer of picking and eating, we sometimes need to get a little more creative.
Go carb-free with this ready-for-the-dinner-party eggplant wrap. Crispy on the outside, gooey on the inside from cheddar, these are going to get people talking.
We love Italian sandwiches, but we'll never turn down a pasta, especially when it uses grilled sausage and sweet peppers, our favorite Italian sandwich filings.
Eggplant-stuffed eggplants are so delicious, especially when you get spicy lentils and goat cheese. Eggplants are sensitive to cold; protect them in plastic wrap before refrigerating.
Want to boost flavor and go the extra step with your grilled vegetables? Use wood or savory herbs in the fire for a quick flavor infusion.
This Greek yogurt combined with pomegranate sauce becomes a zesty condiment that works with the meaty eggplant.
We love quinoa cakes, but you know what makes them better? A tomato and eggplant caponata. Get smoky flavors from both the eggplant and smoked mozzarella.
This rustic French stew has zucchini, tomatoes, hearty chickpeas, and plenty of eggplant.
Pair the meaty eggplant with punchy pickled beets, salty feta, and fresh herbs.

items.dek: If you forget to thaw the shrimp in the morning, set the bag in a large bowl filled with cold water. It will defrost in minutes. One cup of dry rice will yield 3 cups cooked; leftover rice, which is slightly dried out, makes the best stir-fries.
items.promoDek: The whole family will love this fried rice, and you'll love how fast dinner comes together.

items.socialDescription: This recipe comes from New York chef Deuki Hong's father and has origins in North Korea, the ancestral home of mandu. (Sharing a border with China, it is no coincidence that mandu sounds a lot like the Chinese word for steamed bread, mantou.) Unlike versions stuffed with finely chopped kimchi, Deuki grew up eating mandu with kimchi on the side. The star in this recipe is the very generous quantity of butter, which is mixed in with the pork, garlic and ginger and adds a real-deal richness to each bite. Not typically used in East Asian cooking, butter is a fully Americanized, fully awesome way to rethink the mandu.
items.dek: This recipe comes from New York chef Deuki Hong's father and has origins in North Korea, the ancestral home of mandu. The star in this recipe is the very generous quantity of butter, which is mixed in with the pork, garlic and ginger and adds a real-deal richness to each bite. Not typically used in East Asian cooking, butter is a fully Americanized, fully awesome way to rethink the mandu.

items.dek: Don't obsess over getting these exact ingredients in this precise combination. Any nut you like will work here for crunch, and you're looking for a mix of bright herbs and enough cooked grains to make it substantial.
items.promoDek: Use this recipe as a blueprint, and turn it into dinner based on whatever you find at the farmers' market.
items.socialDescription: Don't obsess over getting these exact ingredients in this precise combination. Any nut you like will work here for crunch, and you're looking for a mix of bright herbs and enough cooked grains to make it substantial.

items.dek: These vibrant, savory, and slightly spicy deviled eggs are perfect for parties, but easy enough to make as a snack, too.
items.promoDek: These vibrant, savory, and slightly spicy deviled eggs are perfect for parties, but easy enough to make as a snack, too.

items.dek: There is nothing like fresh corn on the cob, quickly boiled, spread with lots of sweet butter, and sprinkled with salt. Two ears per person may seem like a proper serving, but appetites run high when corn is in season and freshly picked.
